summary:
The Security Council, 
Recalling previous resolutions and statements on Liberia, 
Expressing concern at the dire consequences of the prolonged conflict, 
Stressing the urgent need for humanitarian assistance, 
Deploring human rights violations, particularly atrocities against civilians, 
Emphasizing the need for parties to safeguard humanitarian workers and UN personnel, 
Mindful of the need for accountability for international humanitarian law violations, 
Reiterating support for ECOWAS efforts, 
Welcoming African Union support for ECOWAS, 
Commending ECOMIL forces deployment, 
Noting lasting stability in Liberia depends on peace in the subregion, 
Gravely concerned by the use of child soldiers, 
Reaffirming support for the Comprehensive Peace Agreement, 
Reaffirming that parties have primary responsibility for implementing agreements, 
Welcoming former President Taylor's resignation, 
Stressing the importance of the Joint Monitoring Committee, 
Recalling framework for a longer-term UN stabilization force, 
Welcoming Secretary-General's report and recommendations, 
Taking note of Secretary-General's intention to terminate UNOL mandate and transfer functions to UNMIL.
Here is a summarized version of the Security Council document:

The Security Council determines that the situation in Liberia continues to threaten international peace and security, and decides to establish the United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMIL) for 12 months. UNMIL will consist of up to 15,000 military personnel, 250 military observers, 160 staff officers, and 1,115 civilian police officers. 

The mandate of UNMIL includes: 
- Supporting the implementation of the ceasefire agreement 
- Protecting UN personnel, facilities, and civilians 
- Providing humanitarian and human rights assistance 
- Supporting security reform 
- Supporting the implementation of the peace process 

The Council demands that Liberian parties cease hostilities and fulfil their obligations under the Comprehensive Peace Agreement and ceasefire agreement. All parties are called upon to cooperate fully with the deployment and operations of UNMIL. 

The Secretary-General's Special Representative will direct UNMIL operations and coordinate all UN activities in Liberia. The transfer of authority from ECOWAS-led ECOMIL forces to UNMIL is requested to take place on 1 October 2003.
